title: Social issues in Armenia
text:
There are several social issues in Armenia including <a href="poverty">poverty</a>, high <a href="unemployment">unemployment</a> rates, <a href="corruption">corruption</a>, and inadequate <a href="public%20services">public services</a>.
Background.
Following the breakup of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> in 1991, masses of newly unemployed people found themselves with no income. The <a href="planned%20economy">planned economy</a> of <a href="Armenia">Armenia</a> was predominantly based on <a href="Industrial%20society">industry</a> and trade. Following Armenia's independence, society was suddenly forced to rebuild the economy in a national shift towards <a href="economic%20liberalism">economic liberalism</a>. While some citizens who lost their livelihoods opted to transition into <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a>.
Between 2012 and 2018, GDP in Armenia grew by 40.7%. GDP growth is projected to grow in 2021 up to 3.4 percent and will increase up to 4.3 percent in 2022. Following the <a href="2018%20Armenian%20revolution">2018 Armenian revolution</a>, the <a href="Government%20of%20Armenia">Government of Armenia</a> prioritized eliminating corruption and strengthening the economy. The government launched numerous criminal cases against alleged corruption by former high-ranking government officials and their relatives, parliamentarians, the former presidents, and in a few instances, members of the judiciary in a bid to tackle systemic corruption.
Poverty in Armenia.
According to the <a href="World%20Bank">World Bank</a>, after a sharp increase in poverty between 2008 and 2009 following the global financial crisis, poverty in Armenia has dropped continuously since 2010. The national poverty rate fell to its lowest level since 2004, reaching 23.5% in 2018 from a peak of 35.8 percent in 2010.
As of 2019, 26.4% of <a href="Armenians">Armenians</a> live below the national poverty line, with the <a href="covid-19%20pandemic">covid-19 pandemic</a> and the effects of the <a href="2020%20Nagorno-Karabakh%20war">2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war</a> playing a role. Rural populations are particularly vulnerable to poverty. Armenia's poorest citizens are concentrated along the nation's borders, in mountain areas and in earthquake zones. The <a href="Shirak%20Province">Shirak Province</a> in north-eastern Armenia, <a href="Lori%20Province">Lori Province</a> in northern Armenia, and <a href="Kotayk%20Province">Kotayk Province</a> in central Armenia are among the poorest provinces.
Child poverty.
According to <a href="UNICEF">UNICEF</a>, despite overall poverty reduction in Armenia, almost one in three children in the country are poor. The family benefit (FB) scheme is the largest support program to poor families. While the coverage of the population by the FB in Armenia is stable (13.6% of the population in 2016), its targeting needs improvement, so that the poorest and most disadvantaged are not left without essential support.
Since 2010, with UNICEF and World Bank support, Armenia has embarked on the reform of integrated social services in the country, introducing individual case management, local social planning and cooperation among social service providers.
In addition, Armenian law prohibits the sexual exploitation of children and provides for prison sentences of seven to 15 years for conviction of violations. Conviction for child pornography is punishable by imprisonment for up to seven years. The minimum age for consensual sex is 16. On 18 June 2020, the government established a referral mechanism for child victims of trafficking and exploitation. 
Disability rights.
In 2021, authorities remained committed to ending institutionalization of children with disabilities. In April 2021, the government approved the 2020-2023 Comprehensive Program and Action Plan on Fulfillment of the Right to Live in a Family and Harmonious Development of the Child. The program features an alternative care service network, including specialized services for children with disabilities. Armenia plans to guarantee inclusive education by 2025, whereby children with and without disabilities study together in community schools.
A bill on rights of people with disabilities, which is set to replace a 1993 law and contains significant improvements, has not yet been ratified by the parliament.
LGBT rights.
According to <a href="Human%20Rights%20Watch">Human Rights Watch</a>, lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (<a href="LGBT">LGBT</a>) people continue to face harassment, discrimination, and violence in Armenia.
In January 2021, the <a href="United%20Nations%20Human%20Rights%20Council">United Nations Human Rights Council</a> held the Universal Periodic Review of Armenia. In the council’s report, Armenia received numerous recommendations, including to ratify the <a href="Istanbul%20Convention">Istanbul Convention</a> without further delay; strengthen anti-discrimination policies; and criminalize all forms of torture and ill-treatment.
Environmental issues.
According to <a href="Amnesty%20International">Amnesty International</a>, <a href="mining">mining</a> for minerals has created significant challenges for environmental protection in Armenia.
<a href="Deforestation">Deforestation</a> was particularly severe during the early 1990s. However, initiatives like the <a href="Armenia%20Tree%20Project">Armenia Tree Project</a> has seen significant <a href="reforestation">reforestation</a> efforts. The initiative has planted more than 6.5 million trees in communities throughout Armenia.
Other issues.
A 2020 report conducted by the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20State">United States Department of State</a> found that Armenian authorities generally respected rights of citizens as enshrined by the <a href="Constitution%20of%20Armenia">Constitution of Armenia</a>. This includes, the right to <a href="Freedom%20of%20assembly">peaceful assembly</a>, the <a href="right%20to%20a%20fair%20trial">right to a fair trial</a>, allowing academic and cultural freedom, <a href="freedom%20of%20religion">freedom of religion</a>, <a href="freedom%20of%20movement">freedom of movement</a>, not restricting or disrupting access to the <a href="internet">internet</a> or censoring online content, respecting <a href="freedom%20of%20expression">freedom of expression</a> for citizens and media, upholding rights to privacy and confidentiality, and ensuring no <a href="political%20prisoners">political prisoners</a> were held in the country. 
Refugees.
In addition, the report concluded that authorities cooperated with the <a href="United%20Nations%20High%20Commissioner%20for%20Refugees">United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees</a> to safeguard the rights of refugees, asylum seekers, and prevent abuse towards migrants. As of 10 August 2020, there were 976 <a href="stateless%20persons">stateless persons</a> in Armenia. Armenian law provides for the provision of nationality to stateless children born within the country’s territory.
Elections.
In 2018, the <a href="Organization%20for%20Security%20and%20Co-operation%20in%20Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a>, determined that elections in Armenia are generally free and fair. The report noted that election campaigning generally allowed equal opportunities for all contestants and that fundamental freedoms of association, assembly, expression and movement were fully respected. The report also concluded that Armenian law does not restrict the registration or activity of political parties.
Domestic violence.
<a href="Domestic%20violence">Domestic violence</a> is prosecuted under general statutes dealing with violence and carries various sentences depending on the charge (murder, battery, light battery, rape, etc.). Meanwhile, rape is a criminal offense, and conviction carries a maximum sentence of 15 years. Domestic violence against women was widespread and was exacerbated by COVID-19 restrictions on movement. According to some officials, the absence of a definition of domestic violence in the criminal code hampered their ability to fight domestic violence. 
Discrimination.
Men and women enjoy equal legal status, however, discrimination based on gender was a continuing problem in both the public and private sectors. There were reports of discrimination against women with respect to occupation, employment, and pay. Women remain underrepresented in leadership positions in all branches and at all levels of government. 
International cooperation.
Effects of partnership between Armenia and the ADB.
The partnership between the <a href="Asian%20Development%20Bank">Asian Development Bank</a> (ADB) and Armenia affected the <a href="economy%20of%20Armenia">economy of Armenia</a> positively. One of the advantages of this partnership includes the modernization of technologies and innovation. It has also created a better business environment for the locals and foreign investors, as well as increase private sector investment and overall economic growth.
According to the Asian Development Bank, as of 2020, the unemployment rate increased to 20.2%, while the proportion of employed people who receive less than 1.9$ PPP a day is 0.3%. Meanwhile, the under 5 <a href="child%20mortality">child mortality</a> rate equals 12 per 1000 children. 
Eliminating poverty is one of the sustainable development goals promoted by the ADB. In addition, the other primary goals are <a href="Sustainable%20Development%20Goal%202">zero hunger</a>, good health and well-being, gender equality, clean water and sanitation, affordable and clean energy, decent work and economic growth, industry, innovation, and infrastructure, reducing inequalities, growing sustainable cities and communities, promoting responsible consumption and production, and developing further partnerships to achieve these goals.
Effects of partnership between Armenia and the EU.
The <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> is the biggest provider of financial support and a key reform partner in Armenia. As part of the <a href="European%20Neighbourhood%20Policy">European Neighbourhood Policy</a>, Armenia benefits from EU financial assistance. The amount allocated to Armenia depends on Armenia's commitment to reforms. In July 2021, EU Commissioner for Neighborhood and Enlargement <a href="Oliver%20Varhelyi">Oliver Varhelyi</a> announced that the EU will be granting an amount of approximately $3.1 billion USD in aid to Armenia, a 62% increase than the amount promised before.
The <a href="Armenia-EU%20Comprehensive%20and%20Enhanced%20Partnership%20Agreement">Armenia-EU Comprehensive and Enhanced Partnership Agreement</a> was entered into force on 1 March 2021. The agreement advances the bilateral relations between the EU and Armenia and includes clauses on improving <a href="democracy">democracy</a>, justice, protecting <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a> and minority rights, rural development, employment and social affairs, fighting corruption, and increasing environmental protection.
